author: Special Correspondent
text:
Speaking about the protest that writers and Sahitya Akademi awardees initiated last year in protest against Dadri lynching and the killing of writers and rationalists, including M.M. Kalburgi, writer and poet Ashok Vajpeyi, who also returned his award, said on Monday that it was “sad” some writers now agreed to take back the awards they had returned.

(Writer Nayantara Sahgal recently denied that she took back the Sahitya Akademi award.)

He, however, said the writers were conferred with the awards individually and hence had the right to take them back.

‘Greater than the cause’

On whether the re-acceptance of awards has weakened the cause of the protest, Mr. Vajpeyi said for some, the award had become greater than the cause.

Mr. Vajpeyi, who recently returned the D.Litt. degree accorded to him by the University of Hyderabad for its “anti-Dalit attitude,” which has become a talking point after the suicide of research scholar Rohith Vemula, said: “According to me, the situation in the country has worsened.”

Hindi writer Uday Prakash, who also returned his award as a protest against the Akademi’s “silence” over the killing of Mr. Kalburgi, told The Hindu:

“A few returned the awards because they wanted to save their faces since they might have felt they were under pressure.”

‘They were given the awards individually and have the right to take them back’
title: Sad some writers are taking back awards: Ashok Vajpeyi
